12.title: Hoople, Amos
12.author: Gene Ahern
12.series: Jan. 27, 1922) "Mrs. Hoople's Globe Trotting Husband Comes Back Home!"
12.appears_in: reprinted on p. 9 of The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 3 (1970).
notes: Summary: Martha and a houseful of boarders greet Amos, who has been "gone nigh on ten years!"
Editor's note says this is the "first appearance of Major Amos Barnaby Hoople."

13.title: Hoople, Amos
13.author: [No author]
13.series: Jan. 14, 1954) "As a Matter of Fact, the Brace is News to Him"
notes: Summary: Amos presents drawings of his coat with the built-in chair, and the boarders point out a structural difficulty.

14.title: Hoople, Amos
14.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major is hiding and reading in the hayloft to avoid work, except at mealtimes.

15.heading: Hoople, Amos--Miscellanea.

15.author: Bob Adelman (New York : Simon & Schuster, 1997).
notes: A Tijuana bible reprint.

16.title: "Major Hoople : A Comic Hero in the American Tradition"
16.author: by Terry J
16.appears_in: Scullin. 34 p. in The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 3 (1970).
notes: About Our Boarding House.
Includes a cast of characters.

17.heading: Hoople, Amos--Miscellanea.
17.title: "Major Hoople in Phht" p. 33 in Tijuana Bibles, Art and Wit in America's Forbidden Funnies, 1930s-1950s
17.author: Bob Adelman (New York : Simon & Schuster, 1997).
notes: A Tijuana bible reprint.

18.heading: Hoople, Amos--Miscellanea.
18.title: "There Was a Real Hoople"
18.author: by Russ Winterbotham
18.appears_in: 5 p. in The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 3 (1970).
notes: About Our Boarding House.

19.title: Hoople, Hannibal
19.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Pop arrives for a visit and sees Amos and Jake painting the house, albeit not very energetically.

20.title: Hoople, Hannibal
20.author: [No author]
20.series: June 12, 1945) "Unpack, Dad, and Have a Cup of Tea"
notes: Summary: The elder Hoople begins his visit by handing Martha $100 "for steering my son Amos away from the men with the butterfly nets all these years."

21.title: Hoople, Hannibal
21.author: [No author]
21.series: Feb. 7, 1956) "The Old Gent is Younger than the Major"
notes: Summary: Hannibal Hoople has seen his son's picture in the newspaper, and is coming to visit and help Amos lose weight.

22.title: Hoople, Hannibal
22.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Pop Hoople has both his sons on their backs seeing stars and birdies, and Buster says it was the best instant peacemaking he's seen since the vigilantes lost their rope.

23.title: Hoople, Hannibal
23.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Neighbor Harvey Baxter is in his yard with his push mower as Amos' father leaves on his motorcycle; Amos is about to launch a story about a special assignment for the governor.

24.title: Hoople, Jake
24.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos and Jake are thinking up schemes to decide who will be Pike's bodyguard.

25.title: Hoople, Jake
25.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Jake Hoople arrives and asks where the old parlor ornament (his brother) is; Martha tells him Amos is working.

26.title: Hoople, Jake
26.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major is pacing in a cloud of cigar smoke trying to figure out how to get the money Jake owes him; a boarder suggests using some habeas corpus double-talk to scare it out of him.

27.title: Hoople, Jake
27.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The boarders want Jake to join their poker game, but Jake is suspicious that Amos is using them somehow to get revenge.

28.title: Hoople, Jake
28.author: Bill Freyse.
28.series: Jan. 29, 1966) "Jake is an Authority on Sure Things"
notes: Summary: The boarders are watching wrestling on television, and talking about how quiet it is with the Professor gone. After cleaning up at poker the Professor is headed for Las Vegas, where he's working on the odds of filling an inside straight, but they think Jake Hoople is a match for him.

29.title: Hoople, Martha
29.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos and Jake are painting the house at what they think is breakneck speed; Martha calls them turtles.

30.title: Hoople, Martha
30.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos is writing a spring song at the piano, that will drown out Mendelssohn. Martha wants to know, given a world of atom bombs, cold war, hot war, reds, jets, taxes and tanks, if the vernal equinox has cracked his bell.
Key words: Musical composition, daffodils.

31.title: Hoople, Martha
31.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Martha reads the Major's essay, and speaks of the patriotism of her folks, the one-shot Rathbuns of Kentucky; he wishes she could be smuggled into the Kremlin with a mop.
Key words: Russia, courage, tigresses, typewriters.

32.title: Hoople, Martha
32.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Civil Defense Committee appoints Major Hoople the auxiliary Fire Chief, and Martha says it's the kind of Sitting Bull operation that should fit him like a nightgown.

33.title: Hoople, Martha
33.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Martha shows Amos's portrait of Shakespeare to Mrs. Snackleby. Neither woman appreciates it, but neither says so out loud.

34.title: Hoople, Martha
34.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Martha wakes Amos at 10:15 with a snap of the window shade, saying "No Work, No Food."

35.title: Hoople, Martha
35.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Martha wakes Amos at 11:15 by poking him with a fishing rod, calling him a groundhog and telling him to get up and see his shadow before she says it in braille; he has missed the fishing contest.

36.heading: Hoople Diction Disc.
36.title: "Is That Good or Bad?"
36.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: President Humm of the record company doesn't dig the Major's culture jazz, but the Hoople Diction Disc is a sleep-producer; it conked out the board of directors.

37.heading: Hoople Diction Disc.
37.title: "Looks Like a Big Day for Everybody"
37.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Amos is on his way to Low Fidelity Records to sign a contract selling the Hoople Dictation Discs; Twiggs has only been watching an apprentice barber shave a wrestler, so he'll come along.

38.heading: Hoople Diction Disc.
38.title: "Run Along Boys, and Don't Disturb Genius at Work"
38.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Now that the Hoople Diction Disc idea has been sold, the boarders expect the Indians to win the next TV western, or has the hearing aid picked up Swahili short-wave again? The Major dismisses them to concentrate on his new practical plans for desalination of sea water.

40.heading: Hoops, Raymond.
40.title: "A Comic Book on the Comics"
40.author: by Raymond Hoops
40.appears_in: p. 48-50 in The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 1 (Summer 1967).
notes: Describes a booklet about comics produced by a class at Fitchburg State College (Mass.)

41.heading: Hoops.
41.title: "I Must Have Just Dreamed About that 6-Foot Growth Spurt"
41.author: Russell Myers.
notes: Summary: He still can't get the basketball up to the hoop.

42.heading: Hoops.

43.heading: Hoops.

58.heading: Hooters.
58.title: Woofers & Hooters
58.author: by Budgett and Dumm.

59.heading: Hootieowl, Grampie and Granny.
59.title: "Toy Airship"
59.author: [No author]
59.series: Johnny Gruelle's Raggedy Ann) 8 p. in New Funnies, no. 98
notes: Summary: The Raggedys take a ride in a lighter-than-air toy, lifted by hot air from a candle and propelled by a rubber band propeller. They land in Grampie and Granny Hootieowl's tree, as they discover their grandchild, Sally Screechowl, has been kidnapped. Kidnapper Walter Weasel has left his paw print, and the Raggedys retrieve her using the airship and a fishhook. Next they accidentally snag a puppy, who takes them home to a little boy, but they escape by finding some new candles to lift the ship.

105.heading: Hoover, J. Edgar, 1895-1972.
105.title: "Special Agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation". First in a series. 7 p. in True Comics, no. 33
105.author: [No author]
notes: (3rd story; pages 8-14 of magazine; featured on 1/6 of cover)
SUMMARY: Covers the training of new recruit Steve Saunders. Firearms, deduction, laboratory work, and law.

NOTE: A notice at the bottom of the first page of each episode in this series reads: "This series is presented with the cooperation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The situations presented in this series are true, and the characters are authentic with the exception of 'Steve Saunders' who has been created as a typical example of the caliber of men who make up the intelligent and courageous personnel of the FBI." At the end of each episode is a letter from J. Edgar Hoover to the reader. 1. United States. Federal Bureau of Investigation. k. Training. k. Recruits. k. Firearms. k. Deduction. k. Laboratory work. k. Law. I. Hoover, J. Edgar. Call no.: PN6728.1.P3T7no.33
